Finding aid for
Perry Bullard papers, 1969-1992

Finding aid created by
Michigan Historical Collections staff

did.abstract: The Perry Bullard Papers (1973-1992) document Bullard's service as a state representative from Michigan's 53rd district, primarily between the years of 1980 and 1992. The collection contains correspondence, newspaper clippings, committee reports and studies, bills, and briefing material on issues that came before the Michigan House of Representatives between 1973 and 1992.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: Perry Bullard (donor no. 6263) began donating his papers to the library in 1979. He and his staff have made periodic additions from that time until his retirement from office in 1993.

accruals.p: No further additions to the papers are expected.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open to research.

userestrict.p: Copyright has been transferred to the regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, Perry Bullard papers, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: Perry Bullard was born September 2, 1942 in Cleveland, Ohio. He received a bachelor's degree from Harvard in 1964. From 1964 until 1968 he served in the United States Navy. Returning to civilian life, he entered the law school of the University of Michigan, from which he graduated in 1970. In 1971 he became the law clerk to Justice Paul Adams of the Michigan Supreme Court. In November 1972 he was elected to the Michigan House of Representatives. He won re-election in the 1974, 1976, 1978, 1980, 1982, 1984, 1986, 1988 and 1990 elections. In 1981, Bullard became Chairman of the House Judiciary Committee. While in the House, Bullard sponsored more than 100 bills that were enacted into law. Among them were the Open Meetings Act and the state Freedom of Information Act.
In 1992, Bullard decided not to seek reelection to the House and instead ran unsuccessfully for judge of the 15th District Court.

scopecontent.p: The Perry Bullard papers document his twenty year career in the Michigan House of Representatives, especially as chairman of the House Judiciary Committee. The collection includes both Bullard files and files maintained by members of his staff. The files document the passage of acts (or failure of bills) through correspondence, staff memoranda, communications from constituents and lobbying groups, and all manner of background and printed material. The series in the collection are Correspondence; Legislative Files; House Judiciary Committee files; Topical Files; Political and Campaign materials; Publicity, Speeches, Clippings; and Personal Materials.

The Correspondence series covers the period of 1978 to 1990 (1987 letters are lacking). The correspondence is arranged by year and then alphabetically. The letters are from Bullard's constituents and cover a range of topics from personal individual concerns, politics, general legislative matters, and constituent opposition or support of specific pieces of legislation.

The bulk of the collection consists of Legislative Files from the period when Bullard first entered the Legislature to the end of his last term in 1992. The files are of Bullard himself and some of his key staff, notably David Cahill, who was counsel to the chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, and Brad Geller, who was Bullard's personal aide.

The files have been largely left in the order in which they were received. Thus there are materials relating to a specific legislative term and there are files related to topics about which there was considerable contention and which often carried over from one term to the next. These Legislative Files seemed to divide naturally into two subseries: Major Topics / Multiple Legislative Sessions and Miscellaneous legislation / Staff files.

"Major Topics / Multiple Legislative Sessions" consists of files pertaining to the major pieces of legislation supported by Bullard. These included legislation relating to the issues of plant relocation, the divestiture of state assets from companies doing business in South Africa or with its apartheid government, tort or liability reform, marijuana legalization, right-to-die legislation, among other topics.

odd.p: (repeal of the State Police Subversive Activities Act)

did.unittitle: Reauthorization of Office of Criminal Justice 1982-1985

scopecontent.p: The second legislative subseries relates to more various pieces of legislation, largely coming out of the House Judiciary Committee. These files have been maintained by legislative session and House or Senate Bill number. Some of the legislative files, those maintained by either David Cahill or Brad Geller, are arranged by date. These files are valuable in their documentation of the progress of a piece of legislation through the Legislature and the full House. Included are copies of the bill, drafts and other modifications, and memoranda to Bullard from staff discussing or offering criticism of a bill. The files also contain background information about the topic covered by the legislation.

scopecontent.p: Associated with these files is a small series of House Judiciary Committee files. These consist of agenda of the meeting of the committee and a scattering of materials from the various subcommittees.

An important, but somewhat disparate series, is the Topical Files. Over the course of his career, Perry Bullard and his staff made more than forty separate accessions of materials to the library. These came to the library as material was no longer needed or as file space was required. The most convenient way to deal with this material was to create subject files, largely by chronological blocks of time, but with much overlap. There are currently four separate topical files with information on all public policy issues, citizen concerns, and specific pieces of legislation. These sets of Topical Files should be used with the Legislative Files for material on South Africa Divestiture among other topics.

scopecontent.p: Received with the Bullard papers were materials which he received from his predecessor of the House Judiciary Committee Bob Traxler and from the counsels who served the committee Bruce A. Timmons and Greg Kershuls. Most of these files relate to revision of the Uniform Controlled Substances Act in 1971-1972.

did.unittitle: HB4882 Revised Uniform Controlled Substances Act 1971-1972
HB4882 Revised Uniform Controlled Substances Act 1971-1972

scopecontent.p: Also received with the Bullard papers were files of the Michigan Law Revision Commission, 1969-1972. These were probably files maintained by Bruce A. Timmons.

odd.p: (probably files of Judiciary Committee counsel Bruce Timmons)

(probably files of Judiciary Committee counsel Bruce Timmons)

scopecontent.p: The Political and Campaign materials series largely concerns Bullard's election and re-election campaigns. Included are campaign literature of Bullard and his opponent, and strategies on running a campaign. Also of interest are material relating to the effort to have Bullard and other colleagues recalled from office in 1983.

did.unittitle: Recall effort against Bullard and other state legislators 1983

scopecontent.p: The Publicity, Speeches, Clippings series includes press releases (1972-1992), newsletters sent to his constituents, letters he wrote to the editor of newspapers, transcripts of responses he made to television editorials, and political speeches and addresses within the legislature. There are also miscellaneous clippings with articles about Bullard.

did.unittitle: Guides, handbooks, and other published material distributed by Bullard's office
Letters to the editor, television editorial responses, miscellaneous clippings

scopecontent.p: The Personal series is small and includes biographical materials, a few folders, and a listing of the legislation sponsored by Bullard. This listing only goes to the mid-1970s.

did.unittitle: Biographical material, including early lists (1970s) of legislation sponsored
